title: Pep Guardiola admits he must shoulder the blame for Claudio Bravo's poor form this season
text:

Pep Guardiola has admitted he must shoulder the blame for calamity keeper Claudio Bravo’s woeful form this season. 
Bravo was the fall-guy last weekend, as City were hammered 4-0 at Everton, a defeat that prompted City boss Guardiola to concede the title. 
Guardiola admitted dropping Bravo - brought in supposedly as an upgrade for former City No.1 Joe Hart - was an option, but said he still has faith in the Chile stopper. 
While Guardiola would not admit trading Bravo for Hart had backfired, he conceded his own tinkering at the back, in terms of systems and personnel, had been a factor. Guardiola has been discussing his defensive problems (Photo: REUTERS) 
Guardiola has fielded 13 different back-fours and six different back-threes this season, and did not keep same the back five in successive games until December. 
Against that backdrop, Guardiola admitted he was culpable in Bravo’s ongoing struggles, with the City keeper once again in the spotlight for today’s visit of high-flying Tottenham. 
Everton had only four shots on target at Goodison Park but converted them all, a damning statistic that proves the folly of jettisoning Hart for Bravo. 
“I never say the reason why we lost is because of Claudio Bravo,” said Guardiola. “It’s one of the reasons why, but there are many many other reasons why. “But maybe the reason why is because we changed the defence. Maybe, but we’ll never know that. 
“I’m sorry, I’d like to know exactly 100 per cent and then I would not answer ‘maybe’, I would answer you: ‘Yeah, that’s true’, but I’ll never know. 
“You have to accept what happens right now about my job. Of course I’m willing to accept that. 
“What happens in the club, I said many times, in the team, I said many times [is my responsibility]. 
“Always, five minutes after the game finishes, I say ‘what can I do to get the team better. I never in my life blame bad results, the reason why, I never did, I don’t do it.” 
When David De Gea was struggling to adapt to the physical nature of the Premier League in his debut season at Manchester United, Sir Alex Ferguson took him out of the firing line. Bravo watches another goal go past him (Photo: Michael Regan) Read More Pep Guardiola admits Manchester City title chances are OVER 
De Gea returned a more accomplished keeper and has developed a consistency of performance that has seen him become one of Europe’s best keepers. 
Guardiola admitted giving Bravo the same kind of treatment was an option, but will continue to keep faith with him, although another horror show today would force the City coach’s hand. 
“With all the goalkeepers, all of the players, of course it depends on my decisions,” said Guardiola. 
“But until now I’m convinced he is a good player, he’s a good goalkeeper. 
“When I’m going to consider that I’m going to think about that, but at the moment he’s still in goal because, when I speak with Xavi Manchisidor [City’s goalkeeping coach] he will stay in the goal. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
